catalogue_raissonne: Hind 252 only state; B.42; Hollstein 42 ii/ii; Mz.181 ii/ii; B-B.51-D ii/ii
creditline:
The William M. Ladd Collection
Gift of Herschel V. Jones, 1916
provenance: From card: Woodburn, as stated on old mat. Mounted on old piece of cardboard presumably by S. Woodburn, in pen verso (L. 2584). William M. Ladd
text: A succinct embodiment of pathos, this print came toward the end of Rembrandt's long fascination with the Book of Tobit. It focuses on the approach of Tobit's long-absent son while exploring the idea of inner and outer vision. Hearing Tobias's dog, Tobit topples a spinning wheel in his effort to reach the door, which eludes him as he poignantly stumbles toward his shadow. His senses are of little use, Rembrandt implies; Tobit must look to his faith for direction.
title: The Blindness of Tobit
